Award.AwardTitle: PFI:AIR-TT: Technology Translation: Rolled-up 3D Passive Electronic Component Prototype Development
Award.AbstractNarration:
This PFI:AIR Technology Translation project focuses on translating the strain-induced self-roll-up membrane nanotechnology to fill the need to reduce the size of widely used lumped passive components in integrated circuits.   The miniaturization of passive electronic components is important because it will shrink the overall size and weight of wearable devices or allow more functionalities to be implemented without changing the footprint of the electronic components. The project will result in a prototype of an integrated circuit chip with rolled-up passive components, particularly an inductor. This rolled-up inductor has the following unique features: small, light, and high operating frequency. These features provide advantages including better wearability and higher frequency mobile communications when compared to the leading competing planar coil inductors and other passive components in this market space.  

This project addresses the following technology gaps as it translates the strain-induced self-rolled-up membrane (S-RuM) based passive components from research discovery toward commercial application. The current widely used lumped passive components, especially planar inductors in monolithic integrated circuits (ICs) have several drawbacks that include large on-wafer footprint (occupy as much as 90% of the IC), low operation frequency, and sensitivity to substrate doping levels and deformation. One of the solutions to solve these problems is to use three-dimensional (3D) structures, because hierarchical 3D structures enable efficient use of materials without changing the footprint in plane and lead to advanced functionalities that are otherwise out of reach. However, if conventional fabrication technologies are used to produce 3D structures, issues such as mechanical stability, conformity, alignment, process complexity and cost are difficult to address. The S-RuM based passive technology provides a revolutionary platform because of the self-assembly nature, which produces a 3D cylindrical structure from a 2D layout spontaneously once released from the mechanical support, minimizing mechanical stability concerns by avoiding processing on suspended or curved surfaces. The CMOS-compatibility of the materials and processes also makes integration with active devices and other passive components feasible. In contrast to the planar counterpart, this 3D platform promises to produce IC chips with dramatically enhanced inductance density, superior Q factor/frequency, and minimized substrate coupling.

Personnel involved in this project, including one graduate student and two undergraduate students, will receive innovation and technology translation experiences through making a functional prototype that meets the needs of potential customers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Miniaturization of passive electronic components is important because it will shrink the overall size and weight of devices or allow more functionalities to be implemented without changing the footprint of the electronic components. Hierarchical three-dimensional (3D) structures enable efficient use of materials and lead to advanced functionalities that are otherwise out of reach. Through this program, we have explored the translational pathway of applying the strain-induced self-roll-up membrane nanotechnology to fill the market need to reduce the size of the widely used lumped passive components, particularly inductors, in high frequency integrated circuits. The major intellectual outcomes of research supported by this grant include the inherently interdisciplinary insight in addressing the feasibility and reliability of a new device miniaturization technology; the physical understanding of the energy confinement and storage limitation in 3D on-chip passive devices and coupling between devices when integrated; and the holistic systematic approach in device integration and design integration in making complex 3D architectures with ultrasmall physical footprint and transformative device capability. For workforce development, this grant partially supported the completion of one MS thesis and two graduate students. Through this program, students were provided with training and professional development opportunities in not only hands-on technical experience in chemical vapor deposition, lithography, metal deposition, and other cleanroom fabrication processing, and materials characterization, electromagnetics modeling, but also entrepreneurial mind set and practical experience in building prototypes, as well as team work through collaborations. The impact on the broader communities include the incorporation of the research outcome in a graduate level course on advanced semiconductor nanotechnology and the lectures for the Girls Learning Electrical Engineering summer camps. This program also enriched the infrastructure of the Holonyak Micro and Nanotechnology Lab by our students’ essential role in calibrating the plasma-enhanced chemical vapor deposition tool, which is essential to ensure controlled stress in the self-rolled up membrane based 3D inductors. This benefits more users beyond the PI’s research group and this project. Throughout the entire program, the PIs have contributed to the promotion of diversity and inclusivity environment by actively mentoring students and junior faculty.


Last Modified: 02/20/2021
Modified by: Xiuling Li

Hierarchical three-dimensional (3D) structures enable efficient use of materials and lead to advanced functionalities that are otherwise out of reach. Through this program, we have explored the translational pathway of applying the strain-induced self-roll-up membrane nanotechnology to fill the market need to reduce the size of the widely used lumped passive components, particularly inductors, in high frequency integrated circuits. The major intellectual outcomes of research supported by this grant include the inherently interdisciplinary insight in addressing the feasibility and reliability of a new device miniaturization technology; the physical understanding of the energy confinement and storage limitation in 3D on-chip passive devices and coupling between devices when integrated; and the holistic systematic approach in device integration and design integration in making complex 3D architectures with ultrasmall physical footprint and transformative device capability. For workforce development, this grant partially supported the completion of one MS thesis and two graduate students. Through this program, students were provided with training and professional development opportunities in not only hands-on technical experience in chemical vapor deposition, lithography, metal deposition, and other cleanroom fabrication processing, and materials characterization, electromagnetics modeling, but also entrepreneurial mind set and practical experience in building prototypes, as well as team work through collaborations. The impact on the broader communities include the incorporation of the research outcome in a graduate level course on advanced semiconductor nanotechnology and the lectures for the Girls Learning Electrical Engineering summer camps. This benefits more users beyond the PI’s research group and this project.
